intro: Corispermum heptapotamicum, commonly known as the seven-leafed sandmat, is a flowering plant native to arid and semi-arid regions of Central Asia. It belongs to the family Chenopodiaceae, which includes many salt-tolerant species. The plant is characterized by its compact, cushion-like growth form and small, scale-like leaves that help reduce water loss. Its flowers are typically greenish-white and clustered in inflorescences, adapted to the harsh environmental conditions of its habitat. Corispermum heptapotamicum plays a role in stabilizing sandy soils and is often found in desert ecosystems.
